text: can you hear me at the back give me a wave can hear me thank you everybody so good afternoon everyone my name is matt
woods i am the chief data scientist here at amazon web services that basically means that i get to come and talk to
smart people such as yourselves about any uh high performance computing related needs you might have or any
workflows that you're running my background is in hpc and in data analytics i worked on the human genome
before joining amazon i helped set up the next generation dna sequencing pipeline back in cambridge in the uk
and in the time that i've been at amazon which is probably getting on for three and a half years now um we've seen the
story of hpc uh changed significantly uh so when we first launched amazon ec2 way
back in november 2006 we spotted very quickly the customers started to use this programmable utility
computing environment to run um analytics scale out workflows basically
so they were able to take this utility computing environment program it deploy it very very large scale and i could
talk about iops and interconnects and all those things all day long but what our customers really found early on was that
the this utility general purpose platform that we had with ec2 was really starting to remove the
constraints around their high performance workloads so it's starting to change the way that they were
thinking about the problems that they were trying to solve and the questions that they were trying to ask of their data and there was a a very large and it
continues to be a very large pent-up demand for high performance computing because traditionally in the sort of old
traditional infrastructure world almost all hpc is resource constrained
you have to try and figure out based on queue lengths based on the capacity that you have available to you either if
you're lucky enough to have access to a super computing center or if you have the cluster under your desk you have to
try and figure out what questions can i fit into my hardware what questions can i fit into the resources that i have
available to me today and what we found very early on with ec2 was that customers started to pick up that those
resources started to melt away in the cloud they found out that they didn't have to worry about fitting their
problem into the resources they had available they were able to start scaling out their problems they were able to start thinking more in terms of
well given how much infrastructure i need do i need to be able to solve a problem so very early on we saw scale out
systems start to appear these were relatively straightforward they would sometimes have cues involved they would
sometimes not they were built around sqs and they were basically for embarrassingly parallel
traditional scale out systems so workloads that decompose very easily into small lumps of compute which you
can then just throw up onto the cloud orchestrate with a queue wait a couple of hours and your results come back in
but increasingly what we started to see was we heard from customers that they basically wanted more and more power so
they wanted to be able to not just run scale out workloads but be able to scale up uh the questions that they were going
to be able to ask on the physical hardware now everything we do at amazon is driven by that customer feedback
so you know give you a sort of insight into how we operate we basically before we write a line of
code for a new service we'll write the press release for what that service is going to be announced it's pr driven
development and we'll write the faq which is real questions that we collect from customers and the basis of this is that everything
that we develop is driven by the questions and the the requests that we get from customers such as your good sales and we heard over and over again
that although the scale-up workloads were operating well and that was allowing the the researchers the academics the
industrial hpc users to be able to start to scale up they also wanted to be able to run more tightly coupled workloads
rather than just embarrassingly parallel so they are asking basically for more cpu firepower they were looking to move
beyond just scale out uh to more tightly coupled parallel processing
so we heard that loud and clear and in november i think a couple of years ago
we launched cluster computing instances so these are specific instances which run on ec2 or
an ec2 instance type which are specifically designed for high performance computing and have a couple
of really really nice features so the first is that uh we uh start to pull back the curtain about which cpu you're
running on so that you can optimize for your cpu so cc one uh the first generation runs on uh intel and the
halem processors um there's uh quite a lot of firepower in them but more interestingly than that we also
deployed those onto a specially designed uh high performance network this is a 10 gigabit bisectional network which means
that all of your nodes in a cluster can talk at 10 gig all at the same time so um
in addition to that we also wanted to be able to allow customers to control the physical location of the virtual
machines that they were spinning up in the amazon data centers so we introduced the concept of placement groups and this
allows you to spec out a placement group and ec2 will try and launch your instances on hardware which is closely
located within the data center couple that with this high performance 10 gig bisecting network and you can achieve
some pretty impressive scaling requirements but customers hpc customers always want
more and we kept hearing the same thing we want more cpu firepower more cpu firepower so in november at
supercomputing last year we announced the second generation of cluster compute instances which we imaginatively titled
cc2 uh dot 8 extra large is the full api name and these are
running intel e5 sandy bridge processors very very high performance and
nice little back story we actually had them deployed in production available for api and high performance use about
six months before they entered the channel for all of our other partners we had a great relationship with intel
we do a lot of work with them and they did ask us to try and hide which cpu it was any idiot could figure it out but
then about six months later we pulled the uh pulled the um covers off and surprise you're running on sandy bridge
which is then called e5 so these offer very very high performance you can optimize for the sort of performance
benefits you can see for the intel e5 compiling for avx and things like that they are deployed on the same high
performance 10 gig network that all our cluster compute instances are and the day before we announced them
um we were able to run a benchmark not against the whole fleet we had some private beta customers that were using
the infrastructure but around uh a certain amount of the fleet it was around 17 000 cores if i remember
rightly and that benchmarked in at 240 teraflops and we submitted that to the top 500 list and we ranked in uh this is
last year uh in november we ranked in at number 42. this is the world's 42nd most
powerful supercomputer deployed on demand and available for anybody to use um so
that really was uh uh uh a an epoch in the arrival of high performance
computing in the cloud that this was the actually the fastest performing ethernet powered supercomputer in the world
deployed on an elastic infrastructure that's available to everybody so 240 teraflops yeah you can do a lot of
damage one of the problems that we have with with hpc is that uh we are now in general availability and so anybody can
jump in and so we can't renew off our benchmarks very often because we have so many customers actually using the infrastructure so this is the most
up-to-date benchmark we have unfortunately in addition to asking for additional cpu more power
we've also heard from customers that they wanted additional iops they wanted to be able to deliver additional read and write performance and so in about
six months ago i think we started to introduce the concept of provision throughput to the elastic
block store devices where you could reserve the capacity your application needed to specific block stores ebs if
you're not familiar if you're new to aws is a persistent block store you can format it in any way that you like and
provision iops allows you to basically set aside a and reserve the i o
performance your application is going to need and you can raid these things together to drive even more performance aggressive
so if you're running high-formance workloads cc2 is really where you want to be aiming cc1 is perfect for spot
usage if you're not familiar with spot spot is a way of you basically
controlling and naming your price for the super computing usage that you want to want to uh provision
so we have uh this utility computing platform and we want to enable maximum
utilization of that platform we want as many people to be able to use it as possible because that improves our economies of scale it allows us to
operate more efficiently on our data centers and we're able to pass those savings as andy was mentioning this morning back onto our customers now we
do that in a couple of different ways so we go to our hardware vendors and we custom design our hardware to make sure we don't have usb ports and things like
that but we also do it using various different pricing structures so a certain amount of our capacity inside
our data centers is filled up with reserved instances this is guaranteed capacity that people reserve for up to
one or three years ahead of schedule and it's always there for them as and when they need it and that again allows us to
plan operationally more efficiently and so we're able to pass on in return for a small upfront fee a lower on-demand
hourly price for those instances then that fills up a certain amount in our data centers beyond that we have uh
on-demand access so people spinning up uh the the resources that they need as and when they need them we have enough customers
across the world that that tends to equal out so um you know one customer's peak tends to coincide with another
customer's trough but we typically still have a gap inside our infrastructure a capacity gap and we want to be able to
fill that as much as possible so we actually allow customers to bid on that unused capacity and name your own price
for it um you can jump up onto the website you can actually graph the spot price we recompute it every hour
you place the bid that you want to run your infrastructure at you can name it whatever you want and uh you set your
bid as soon as the spot price goes beneath your bid price will provision that infrastructure for you uh the deal
being that if we need it back again for any reason uh the spot price will increase and if it goes above your bid price we'll take it back again so you do
have to architect for the fact that interruption can occur check pointing is really critical with spot
but you can achieve significant scale and significant cost savings by running on this additional capacity so cc1 is a
perfect use case for this cc2 you can get some great deals with cc one is uh is absolutely perfect for spot as well
so couple that with provisioned iops couple that with new instance types which have a dedicated network back to
the storage you can start to build out some very very high performance systems and on that i would like to welcome your
feedback but also welcome some of the people that are designing and deploying these high performance systems in the
cloud to try and give you guys some insight into the workloads that we're seeing that work well we'll try and get some hints and tips
out there from some real pioneers in this area so on that note i would like to uh
welcome up on stage uh dave fellowes dave is the cto at greenbutton and he's going to talk through what green button
are up to their background and i think do a live demo yeah fantastic there we go thanks matt another little clicker
so hi everyone uh you could say our company green button was born out of the lord of the rings saga where our founder
uh scott houston was the cto any lord of the rings fans yeah cool got a few looking forward to
the hobbit i presume and so with uh two months to go to the launch of return of the king
the final movie in the trilogy they discovered that they had to build a brand new data center a fourth data
center just to get that movie out on time and so it was really if i can click through there were shots
like these the the battle of palinar fields where you've got thousands of characters that are individually
generated by software and placed on that battlefield and they estimated that to render a single frame was going to take
around 600 hours eek so they went ahead and built this brand new data center in a great rate of
knots ibm put the new blades onto a private jet and with them to wellington and new zealand and they had a
helicopter dropping kit to the site daily it was it was quite an operation and so they got this data center built
in 10 days which is a remarkable feat i think uh and this costs him around five
million dollars now this is all for only around five or six weeks work and then this kit was
actually going to sit idle for three years until the final production of king kong was going to kick off a bit of a
waste really so it was realizing that there had to be a better way that was really the
catalyst for what has now become quite a sophisticated software platform for managing big compute workloads across a
variety of different clouds both private and public and amazon's hpc platform is an ideal
platform for a lot of these workflows particularly those that have got large data requirements and heavy i o large
data sets and heavy i o requirements and so green button have partnered with
the number of isvs across different industries pixar is a good example we've taken their renderman software enabled
that to run in the cloud and now that's available to end users as an on-demand
service and they pay a single transactional uh price which includes everything the compute the storage
as well as the isvs license as well so that's pretty key very cost effective for those spiky workloads
so working now with another industries as well financial services biotechnology
engineering design uh but today i want to focus on some of the work we're doing with amazon and one of our partners gns
in the oil and gas space and so gns with their product globe claritas
a leading seismic processing software provider for the oil and gas industry
and so what happens in this oil and gas space is the the all companies when they're searching for new oil will drag
these big long lines across behind these data acquisition ships and follow small explosions and measure
the resulting seismic activity it actually looks a lot more like that but that picture wasn't quite as
attractive so and so from this they can paint a fairly detailed 2d and 3d model of the ocean's
floor the subsurface of the ocean floor and hopefully find out where that pesky oil is hiding
now the resulting data can be fairly massive a typical project may result in
around 50 terabytes of data and so getting this into the cloud can be somewhat challenging
but never underestimate the power of traditional technologies such as fedex
and so the latency is pretty rubbish but the bandwidth is is pretty jaw dropping
and so we ship the stuff stuff up up into amazon and when it gets there we load it into
this cluster file system and gluster is very cool it's a clustered file system that you can scale out to support
whatever i o you need and so depending on how many calls we're going to have to provision for this particular
project we can adjust the size of this cluster we then have a visualization node
and so obviously when these guys run these the end users run these jobs we don't want to be driving fedex trucks backwards and
forwards so the the entire workflow lives in the cloud and so the end users will connect
to visualization node remotely from either their workstation laptop or
even a tablet device like an ipad and through this they can visualize the
outputs and manipulate the data as they go along now when they need to run up a seismic processing job and need the
extra horsepower they send the job off the green button through our rest api
and this virtual machine also hosts a cloud resource controller which will dynamically provision these virtual
clusters on the fly as the jobs come in these are mpi jobs and so each job will
have a virtual cluster provisioned with a head node and a number of child nodes
they'll do their work and save the results back into the gluster file system and and the users can visualize
those outputs um so there's a typical project may run for a number of weeks and what would
normally happen at the end of the project is we'd have to ship all this data back to the customer because they have to keep it on there keep it
recorded or saved somewhere for a number of years but amazon recently announced their glacier service and we heard mention of
that this morning this is really an ideal solution for this problem where you just want to be able to move the data off to somewhere
that's very cost effective you know one cent a gigabyte a month you know a perfect solution for this
problem so just a quick demo
so we're logged in here to the the visualization node running in uh in amazon and i was going to show you some of the
the nice visual outputs you can get from one of these jobs that i've run but it wasn't playing very nicely in this
low resolution so you'll just have to use your imagination but what i have over here on the right
hand side is a another job that i've set up a demo job when i want to submit this to the cloud
i just right click and click select submit and this prompts me for my green button login details and so
this is a good example of where we work with the software vendor to deeply uh integrate with their application this
interface into the cloud so when the end users need extra horsepower they simply click a button
in this case all of the data is is resident in that cluster file system so we don't have to move anything around
but if this is an on-premise application then it would also synchronize any data dependencies
so let's uh supply my login and we can specify the number of processes uh which correlate to the
number of cores that we need for this job this case we'll just select 24
and this will go off and oh it's good it's submitted and if we flick over to the amazon
console here we can see in this environment we have those uh the virtual machines that i described before the
resource controller and api the visualization node as well as a couple of instances for this cluster clustered
file system if we click refresh there we go so these are the three
additional compute nodes or three compute nodes that we've requested to process this job
and once that work is done it will scale that back back down again so in the interest of time we'll quickly
flick back here
and so you know what what's one of these seismic processing jobs look like you know how much compute does it need and
so a typical job running on an eight core server may take around a thousand hours to process
uh and in the oil and gas industry it's you know the competitive advantages and how fast you can turn this data around
and get the results and so with green button and amazon we can run that same job and scale it across 4 000 nodes and
have that run in a little over two hours which is which is pretty pretty impressive speed up and you can run a
number of these jobs in parallel as well so you can really throw a lot of horsepower at this stuff
and we see this is fairly game changing for this industry you know as in others and we hear that term game changing
every other day don't we but you know i think it really is in this case because you have a lot of these small companies
who have really smart people and really clever software and now they can all of a sudden get access to this huge
computing resource that you know would otherwise be outside of their financial reach and compete with the largest companies in their
market so pretty powerful with green button it typically takes around you know a few hours or a small
number of days to get a new workload or a new application uh running up in the cloud
so just to quickly show you some of the tools we have for managing and monitoring jobs you know we can use this to monitor what
the performance characteristics are like on the virtual machines that we have run up this view is pretty cool it shows us all
the deployments we have across different cloud data centers uh globally and so enterprises can see uh you know what
they have deployed out in the cloud across their private and public clouds and get a snapshot of everything uh you know what that's costing them and drill
into uh where that cost has been attributed we have other governance features around chargeback and being
able to set thresholds at different levels of an organization
this is our patented secret source our job prediction which is uh we'll be able
to profile jobs and our commercial engine then turns that into offers so the end user can
decide you know rather than worrying about how many calls are spinning up they can focus on you know how fast do i
need the results back and you know what's the price point that i'm willing to pay and find that balance and we
commit to that that price point so they pay no more than than what's quoted to them
cool cool so thank you for allowing me to do a quick whirlwind tour of green button uh if you you know love to hear

after this talk and floating around the amazon booth as well so thanks a lot
thank you dave so i think it's really interesting one of the one of the things that uh uh the
cloud is kind of bringing up is exposing the cost of computational runs uh to the user and allowing them to make the sort
of uh cost-benefit call on the run that they want to they want to choose so in dave's example exposing the cost to the
user allows them to say well to me this is worth running at a slightly higher cost to get the results back in slightly
less time and being able to achieve that with this sort of utility programmable model is very very empowering
so we have our next speaker up here this is mike driscoll he is the ceo of

and looking back i really wish we had all this aws magic
when we were you know spending millions of dollars with your tax dollars
we could have been spending you know tens of thousands of dollars a month uh with aws so

okay great
perfect um so the title of my talk is data science in the cloud lessons learned with aws
and uh metamarkets has been around for about two years and our goal fundamentally
has been to tame the inferno of the online ad markets and this is a space that we
operate primarily in and some of you may be aware but uh every day there are upwards of 100
billion microtransactions that occur in the online advertising space many of the
ads you see when you go to a site like the new york times or the financial times who's one of our clients many of
those ads are actually determined in real time through an auction system they figure out you know where you're
from they have some idea of where you visited and they try to target some advertising that is specific for
you so there's a lot of data naturally that happens when you've got 100 billion
events a day and at better markets we see a meaningful percentage of that real
time stream so you know what's needed when you're working at that of the scale well
certainly you need fast dashboards to operate over this high volume data you want to be able to
in real time do aggregations over billions of events um you want to have flexible drill downs and you would like
ideally to have sub-second queries so that you can know for instance if in one of the cases we had when godaddy had a
dns outage several publishers were affected well some of our customers wanted to know what's happening in real
time so this is kind of laying the table and i guess it goes without saying that in this space unlike in wall street the
the value of these micro transactions is very low um typically it's about a few dollars to buy a thousand ads online so
um this needs to be cheap right this is where amazon commodity infrastructure
burstable capacity in the cloud makes it possible to get analytics at scale without spending too much money
so we had a few solutions that we attempted the first was your traditional relational database we
initially we worked with postgres and then we used an mpp relational database based on postgres and
the the speed that we got with this was not sufficient this is a picture of our stack
we think of our stack as really a four layer cake we have etl at the bottom we use hadoop we also use kafka
increasingly today we have a data store as a second layer the third layer there we have our own
home boot analytics running and finally we've built some web-based visualizations at the top which i'll show off in a bit but
nonetheless this first solution was not fast enough the second solution we had was actually
what a lot of people do i think when they're building an analytical data stack we use the key value store so
still we had a hadoop at the bottom doing our etl crunching data in hours
and we would store all these pre-computed aggregations in hbase some people use mongodb some people use redis
and this was good uh but it had a couple of problems one is if you've ever built
an architecture like this the challenge is you have to decide in advance all the possible aggregations
that you care about and while that seems okay at first you know in some of our clients cases we
have upwards of 30 or 40 dimensions that people want to aggregate over what's the number of possible ways you
can aggregate 40 dimensions well it scales this 2 to the power of 40. it's a pretty big number
and you can take shortcuts but doesn't scale very well the second issue and this is even more of one is that if you
want to know what's happening right now if you want to know how many people between the ages of 18
and 25 who are from new york new jersey and california clicked on this ad
five minutes ago that information isn't available because it needs to flow through you have to pre-aggregate it
through your hadoop pipeline so we didn't really have real-time insight and it turns out that data freshness is
really important for folks in our space so we thought okay that's not going to work
what we developed instead uh is we did something that maybe we thought was a bit crazy at the time is we said you
know we'll roll our own database and so we built something called druid and we presented this a few weeks ago at strata
in new york we've open sourced this data store because we believe it's something not just that we can use but many other
folks out there might have an interest in it is an in-memory distributed column-oriented data store
and the advantage is really two-fold one is um it allows us to pour data into it
through kafka so we do have real-time data available for querying and secondarily we don't pre-compute any of
the aggregations in druid so everything is primarily stored in memory and we're
able to ask any question about any possible roll up of our data in real time and
what makes this possible for us frankly is having the power of amazon at our back
we have a thousand core cluster that we run today on amazon which our clients
all have access to securely and the nature of analytics often is that it's bursty not everybody shows up
at once to ask a question of their data and we think that cloud and multi-tenancy is a really natural fit to
um to many of the analytics and data science challenges that people have unlike having a you know a big box under
your desk that you use you know once a day or once a week so uh just some some basic numbers uh
for this platform that we're running um we look at uh over a billion events a day um we issue about a hundred thousand
queries daily against that um cluster and the mean response time to the extent that mean response times are are useful
is sub second and that was really our goal we wanted every single query that's run
against our cluster to come back in milliseconds
so you know to go back and say what we're not sort of breaking the laws of physics here right what are the principles of of
uh the performance we get first memory we all know memory is much faster than uh disk uh about a thousand times faster
for reads lately we've been looking at using ssds to back some of our stuff as
well parallelization because we have thousands of cores accessible to us we
get you know typically data is not striped across all of those cores but we get a pretty high parallelization factor for
our data and then the the last piece and of course we distribute the data across um many nodes as well to get that
parallelism the last piece is we do do some summarization so we tokenize and compress the data we
receive and that reduces its overall footprint because we're column oriented we're not pulling entire records out and
scanning full records we're looking only at a particular attribute of a record and again that gives us a little bit of
a speed up in terms of our ability to look at lots of data quickly
interactively and in real time so you know really one distinction we feel for
this infrastructure that we've built on top of amazon is that we built it from the ground up to run on the cloud and
this has given us um a few nice things certainly uh it's elastic
when we've had customers come on board and start pouring lots of data into our system we can
we can move our overall capacity up you know within hours to support that
we also have borrowed a lot from the hadoop ecosystem we use zookeeper to track where all of our data is living
which segments are living on which servers and we have a replication factor for our data which gives us some fault
tolerance so you know right now for instance we're able to do rolling restarts
for all of our machines we don't have to have any downtime for our cluster we can take
nodes down and yet our service you know maintains its reliability and its performance and then
finally a lower total cost of ownership i mean frankly the type of power that we
provide to our end users is something that very few of them could afford to
buy on their own so any one of our our clients would not be interested in paying the the bill that
we pay to amazon uh per month but distribute across many of those clients they're able to achieve some real high
performance computing power but at a fraction of the cost of what it would what it would cost to have
it on on-site or on-premise themselves so these are the the five key features
of druid um i did mention this distributed column store real-time ingestion fast data scans fast filtering
and it's operationally simple to deploy um that picture is a picture that my the lead architect of druid insisted we put
in this talk um that's his his uh apparently what druid looks like to him um as our mascot
uh and then some some benchmarks so you know typically what we see for scan speeds are 33 million records um per
second per core uh we've got ingestion rates of up to ten thousand uh events a second that we can take in again these
are real time advertising markets so we get pretty high qps's there
and then just one data point for a cluster we're running 100 nodes six terabytes of addressable
memory 400 terabytes on disk and we can do a query over six terabytes in memory in
about one and a half seconds so uh it's really possible to get some some great speed here i don't think we have numbers
that will go above what matt gave for the 240 teraflops but if we had a big enough
budget maybe we could try to give you guys a run for your money so with that um i think what i'd like to
